Award.AwardTitle: Statistical Analysis of Incomplete lifetime Data: Theory, Stochastic Models and Empirical Likelihood
Award.AbstractNarration:
The investigator plans to further the development of the theory and statistical methods for the analysis of incomplete lifetime data with special focus on censored data in survival analysis. The proposed research consists of two interrelated research thrusts: (A) The development of the empirical likelihood (EL)-based inference procedures. Motivated by the proven advantages of the EL method, a novel approach is proposed. The PI and her collaborator plan to develop asymptotically optimal statistical procedures that are computationally feasible and efficient, and (B) Extension of the Fix-Neyman competing risks model which focuses on a feature of recurrent events of recovery and relapse of a disease in the model. For many diseases, such as breast cancer and aplastic anemia (AA), recovery and relapse are important events affecting a patient's survival probability. Most of the currently employed competing risks models lack this feature. The research team plans to develop statistical inference procedures under the new model for censored data. The extended model can be applied to other types of recurrent events such as in epidemiology surveys (current status data) and engineering reliability.

Lifetime or "time-to-event" data, commonly collected in science and engineering, could be time to loss of immunity, survival time of a cancer patient after a treatment, time to failure of a bridge and others. Due to sampling methods, sampling subjects, experimental protocols and limitations of recording instruments and possibly other reasons, data sets often contain a significant number of incompletely observed lifetimes. Incomplete data may include right or left censored, interval censored and truncation data. Without proper corrections for incompleteness, data analysis and uncertainty measures would produce biased and unreliable scientific findings. It is therefore of paramount importance to develop sound statistical methods and theory for the analyses of incomplete data. Despite significant advances in theory and applications, burgeoning applications in diverse science fields continues to present new challenging mathematical problems and computational issues. For example, the proposed extension would extend the popular Kaplan-Meier estimator by including recovery and relapse data in the prediction of a patient's survival probability. It is hoped that better utilization of available data would yield more accurate prediction of survival probability for some diseases and help to identify important factors affecting a patient's survival. Developing numerical solutions will be an integral part of the project. Algorithms will be developed for data analysis. The success of the project will advance the statistical theory of incomplete lifetime data and its applications. Novel use of the empirical likelihood method will result in computationally efficient algorithms for applications. Research and education for this project are inseparable. Training of graduate students and recruiting students from under represented group are planned.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Lifetime data analysis is commonly performed in a wide range of scientific disciplines. Depending on the field of applications, researchers address questions, such as, life expectancy of a human being, time-to-failure of a bridge, survival probability of a cancer patient under treatment, the time-to-corrosion of metals, the average lifetime of ultra-cold neutrons and other questions. Lifetime data sets often contains significant number of incomplete measurements. Due to sampling limitations, experimental protocols and data collection costs, incomplete lifetime measurements are unavoidable. However discarding incomplete measurements is not an option because that would produce bias in data analysis. Proper treatment of incomplete data is necessary for the production of reliable scientific findings.

Development of statistical theories and methods for the analysis of incomplete lifetime data is a main area of statistical research. There are various types of incomplete data. Perhaps the most widely studied incomplete data are right censored and randomly truncated (biased) data which are induced largely by sampling methods.

 This project extended the Fix-Neyman competing risks model for the analysis of lifetime data. The model introduced by Fix and Neyman (1951) is for analyzing clinical trials of patients with breast cancer. It is a stochastic model that describes dynamic changes of the disease status of patients under treatment in a clinical trial, including patients' loss to follow-up (now known as right censored). The F-N model offers a unified and general model system for analyzing right-censored lifetime data. With few exceptions, the model has not received much attention. A special feature of the F-N model is the inclusion of recurrent changes of a patient's recovery and relapse information in the model. For many diseases, recovery and relapse are important events affecting a patient's survival probability, and such information is usually available in clinical trials. However, except in some special studies, currently widely used estimators of the survival probability like the Kaplan-Meier estimator do not take into account recovery and relapse information.

 The extension is made in two directions. The F-N model is a 4-state homogeneous (constant transition rates) Markov process.  In one direction, it is theoretically proven that the Fix-Neyman procedure of incorporating right-censored data in the analysis is applicable to a homogeneous Markov process with an arbitrary number of finite states. Another direction of the extension is to allow time-varying transition rates in the 4-state F-N model of which two special cases are investigated. In one case, the extended model incorporates relapse, but without recovery under which a patient's survival probability is derived analytically. Estimation of the survival probability is carried out from which estimates of other parameters of interest can be derived. Algorithms for computation and simulation are developed for practical applications. In another case, the extended model incorporates both recovery and relapse information. In this case, analytical solutions are very difficult to derive. Simulations are used exclusively for obtaining the results.

 In regard to data collection, cross-sectional sampling is one of the most important methods of collecting lifetime data. But cross-sectional data can be length-biased and/or censored. This project studied cross-sectional sampling method systematically. Models are constructed by adhering to the collection method and type of data used, and effects of bias are demonstrated. Nonparametric estimation of the survival function is carried out and its large sample properties are obtained. The models as constructed are different from a widely used length-bias model derived from stationary renewal processes. However, in many practical applications, stationary renewal processes are not very suitable for data analysis. This project provides additional models for applications.

Statistical inference procedures for incomplete data are typically complex. Formulas for estimates, their variances (a measure of uncertainty) and levels of confidence in these estimates are quite complicated.  To find a more efficient way of constructing confidence intervals for parameters of interest for censored data, the PI and collaborators used a modified empirical likelihood to develop a large sample method of constructing confidence intervals for parameters with right censored data. This new method bypasses  the estimation variances that are required in many other empirical likelihood procedures,  improves the coverage accuracy for the parameter, and  eases some of often demanding computations of the empirical likelihood method.

 Results from this project contribute to the development of the statistical theory and methods for incomplete lifetime data, potentially increase the utilization of  available data, and broaden the applications. A graduate student on the project benefited from receiving research training and having her PhD thesis topic derived from this project. This project experience offers her a possible career path as a data analysis in biomedical field.
